document_title: Postpartum hormonal disorders: Causes and signs of recognition
subsection_content:
Postpartum hormonal disorders are postpartum hormonal imbalances, causing physical and emotional changes that women experience during childbirth and the postpartum period.
Estrogen and progesterone increase steadily during pregnancy to produce the placenta. When the placenta is removed at birth, these two hormones will decline rapidly. This drop in estrogen and progesterone is important so that hormones essential for breastfeeding such as prolactin and oxytocin can function, but this drastic change contributes to the emotional lability that is common for several weeks. postpartum head. (2)
Endorphins increase during labor, peak immediately after birth, and decrease after birth. High levels of endorphins support the mother during the birthing process and can help women feel more alert, attentive and even euphoric after giving birth. When this hormone declines in the first few days after giving birth, it can contribute to the mother's mood changes.
In the endocrine system, corticosteroids will reach their highest levels during labor and decrease significantly within 3 hours after birth, when a woman is most emotionally vulnerable.
